Interactions.comment:
This sub-tree contains a list of all possible connections between various particles listed in the particles tree. This information pertains specifically how a particle might change as a result of an interaction. This could, for instance, describe the possible quantum trajectories in a quantum Monte Carlo simulation. Another possible example is describing association and dissociation of molecules and the contributing/resulting constituents.
The standard format for the Eq node is that the particles on each side should be ordered according to: 1. Their mass, from lowest to highest. 2. Their lexigraphically compared names.

cross_section.reference:
Newbury, Myatt, Wieman Phys. Rev. A 51, R2680 (1995).
@Article{Newbury1995a, author = {N.~R. Newbury and C.~J. Myatt and C.~E. Wieman}, title = {s-wave elastic collisions between cold ground-state $^{87}$Rb atoms}, journal = PRA, year = {1995}, volume = {51}, number = {}, month = {}, pages = {R2680-R2683}, pagesf = {4}, url = {http://link.aps.org/abstract/PRA/v51/pR2680}, keywords = {PACS. 34.50.-s, 32.80.Pj, 05.30.Jp } }

reference.notes: Using 100*a_0 as the zero-energy scattering length fits in pretty well with the findings in doi:10.1103/PhysRevA.56.2784 and the references therein, but is an estimation none the less. The reference temperature here was picked almost "out of a hat" so that the values are approximately a bit larger than 87Rb as calculated/shown in doi:10.1103/PhysRevA.56.2784.
reference.bibtex: @Article{Westphal1997lve, title = {Low-velocity elastic scattering of Rb-Rb}, author = {Westphal, P. and Koch, S. and Horn, A. and Schmand, J. and Andr\"a, H. J.}, journal = {Phys. Rev. A}, volume = {56}, number = {4}, pages = {2784--2787}, numpages = {3}, year = {1997}, month = {Oct}, doi = {10.1103/PhysRevA.56.2784}, publisher = {American Physical Society} }

Interactions.cross_section_comment: Cross sections O2 : same as siglo.sec except the 2-body and 3-body attachment cross sections have been separated. Originally based on JILA report, Phelps, 1985, but there are some differences : a) the scale factors for vibrational excitation proposed by Phelps have not been included here b) the 1.6, 8.4 and 10 eV energy losses is somewhat different, partly due to extrapolation.

Interactions.cross_section_comment: Cross sections H2. These are the same as in siglo.sec except for the cross sections for rotational excitation. Scale factors of 16.2 and 1.8 have been applied to the j=0->2 and j=1->3 cross sections, respectively. Dissociative excitation to n=3, balmer alpha, threshold 16.6 eV, has been added. The cross sections below are consistent with the following University of Colorado (May 1, 1985); J. Chem. Phys. 82, 4999 (1985) references : S.J. Buckman and A.V. Phelps, JILA Information Center Report No. 27,

Interaction.comment: It is unclear from the Bolsig+ data set whether 0.2010*eV is the real threshold energy and hence the change in kinetic energy. Following the format that the Bolsig+ authors have used before, I am going to assume that it _is_ the threshold energy. Someone should really examine the original data set. --SEO

Interactions.cross_section_comment: Cross sectins CF4 Same as in siglo.sec except extrapolations to higher energy for vib excitation, set attachment to zero for energy > 10 eV. Y. Nakamura in Gaseous Electronics and its Applications, eds. R.W. Crompton, M. Hayashi, D.E. Boyd, and T. Makabe (KTK Scientific Publishers, Tokyo, Japan, 1991). The vibrational excitation is different than Hayashi's data reported in W.L. Morgan, Plasma Chemistry and Plasma Processing 12, 477 (1992) The first cross section in the list is identified as "elastic" and not "momentum" because it is less than the sum of the inelastics over some energy intervals.

Belenguer and J.P. Boeuf, J. Appl. Phys. 78, 731 (1995) good agreement with mobility and ionization rate calculated using Ne-AVP below.

cross_section.reference: Various sources. See G. Raju, Gaseous Electronics: Theory and Practice, CRC Press, 2006, Table 3.11.

val.comment: G. Raju does indicate that there are very few measurements at low energies and the Ferch et. al data from which part of this comes only covers 0.08eV to 0.1 eV. This data point is not based on anything experimental. I just needed something non-zero at zero energy--as is expected for elastic collision cross sections.
